habitat_description:
The range of the northwestern gartersnake extends from southwestern British Columbia, western Washington, and western Oregon into extreme northwestern California including some coastal islands (Brown et al. 1995; Ernst and Ernst 2003; Nussbaum et al. 1981; Rossman et al. 1996; Stebbins 2003).

This species burrows in or using soil, debris, and leaf litter. While it is considered primarily terrestrial, it is also found in areas near or occasionally in water. It can be found in meadows, edges of thickets, and forest clearings. Hibernation takes place in talus slopes or deep rock crevices (Brown et al. 1995; Ernst and Ernst 2003; Nussbaum et al. 1983; Rossman et al. 1996; Stebbins 2003).

NW	-Associated with edges of thickets, meadows and riparian zones with vast vegetation. It also uses soil, rocks, leaf litter, and fallen logs as cover.
